questions.question: True or False? Newfoundland and Labrador is the only province to have its own time zone in Canada.
questions.feedback: Newfoundland and Labrador has its own time zone, known as Newfoundland Standard Time.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Victoria Cross is the highest honour awarded to Canadians for __________.
questions.feedback: The Victoria Cross is the highest honour awarded to Canadians for bravery.

questions.question: True or False? The Canadian Crown refers to a physical crown owned by the King.
questions.feedback: The Canadian Crown is NOT a physical crown but symbolizes the monarchy and acts as a symbol of Parliament, courts, and armed forces.

questions.question: What is the highest court in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada’s highest court is called the Supreme Court of Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Governor General represents __________ in Canada.
questions.feedback: The Governor General represents the King in Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Canada is a parliamentary democracy which means that Canadians elect their representatives to __________.
questions.feedback: In a parliamentary democracy, Canadians elect representatives to Parliament.

questions.question: Which of the provinces has a provincial police force?
questions.feedback: Ontario and Quebec have provincial police forces.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Lieutenant Colonel John Graves Simcoe and Mary Ann Shadd Cary are well-known for their contribution to the __________.
questions.feedback: Lieutenant Colonel John Graves Simcoe and Mary Ann Shadd Cary are both notable figures in the history of the abolition of slavery.

questions.question: What are the three parts of Parliament?
questions.feedback: Three parts of parliament are the Sovereign, the Senate, and the House of Commons.
options: 1 The Sovereign, the House of Commons, and the Senate
2 The King, the Legislative Assembly, and the Senate
3 The House of Commons, the Legislative Assembly, and the Senate
4 The Sovereign, Governor General, and Prime Minister

questions.question: When was the flag that we use in Canada today first raised on a flagpole?
questions.feedback: The Canadian flag we use today was first raised on a flagpole on February 15, 1965.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The red-white-red pattern of the flag comes from the flag of the __________ in Kingston.
questions.feedback: The red-white-red pattern comes from the flag of the Royal Military College, Kingston, founded in 1876.

questions.question: After a federal election, which party forms the new government?
questions.feedback: When the election is over, the party with the majority of seats in the House of Commons will form the government.
options: 1 The party with the most elected representatives is invited by the Governor General to become the party in power
2 The King himself picks the right party to run the government
3 The Governor General proposes a law for elected officials to become the governing body
4 The Premiers of each province decide on a party to run the government

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Taking care of oneself and one’s family, serving on a jury, and protecting the environment are __________.
questions.feedback: These are all responsibilities of Canadian citizens.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The __________ is a symbol of the Canadian government, the legislatures, the courts, police services, and the Canadian Forces.
questions.feedback: The Canadian Crown symbolizes the government, legislatures, courts, police services, and Canadian Forces.

questions.question: Which of the following Great Lakes is the largest freshwater lake in the world?
questions.feedback: Lake Superior is the largest freshwater lake in the world.

questions.question: What does “presumption of innocence” mean?
questions.feedback: When someone is accused of committing a crime, the justice system must believe that they are innocent until there is enough proof to show guilt.
options: 1 Everyone is innocent until proven guilty
2 Guilt is decided by public opinion
3 Innocence is decided by public opinion
4 Everyone is guilty until proven innocent

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of Canada’s system of government?
questions.feedback: Canada is a federal state, a parliamentary democracy, and a constitutional monarchy.

questions.question: True or False? Helping others in the community is one of many responsibilities that Canadian citizens have.
questions.feedback: Helping others in the community is a responsibility of Canadian citizens.

questions.question: In what industry do most Canadians work?
questions.feedback: More than 75% of working Canadians now have jobs in service industries.

questions.question: What year did Canada’s Confederation happen?
questions.feedback: In Canada, the Confederation was in 1867.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The two principles upon which Canada is founded are the supremacy of God and the ______.
questions.feedback: Canada is founded upon two key principles: the supremacy of God and the rule of law. The rule of law ensures that all individuals and institutions are subject to and accountable under the law, which is a cornerstone of Canadian democracy and justice.

questions.question: How is the Prime Minister chosen?
questions.feedback: When the election is over, the party with the most seats in the House of Commons forms the government. The Governor General invites the leader of this party to become the Prime Minister.
options: 1 The leader of the party with the most elected representatives becomes the Prime Minister
2 The Governor General and the Senate appoint the Prime Minister
3 The King appoints the Prime Minister
4 The MPs vote on the Prime Minister

questions.question: What is the name of the longest bridge in Canada, which is 13 km long?
questions.feedback: PEI is connected to the mainland by the longest bridge in Canada, called the Confederation Bridge.

questions.question: True or False? You can vote in a federal election only on the day of the election.
questions.feedback: In Canada, you can vote in a federal election not only on election day but also during advance voting days, by mail, or at any Elections Canada office before the election. This flexibility ensures that all eligible voters have multiple opportunities to cast their vote.

questions.question: What are the three main groups of Aboriginal peoples?
questions.feedback: The term Aboriginal peoples refers to three groups: The First Nations (Indians), The Inuit, and The Métis.
options: 3 United Empire Loyalists, Métis, and Inuit

questions.question: What do we call the people who fled from slavery in America to come to Canada in the 1780s?
questions.feedback: The people who fled from slavery in America to come to Canada in the 1780s are known as Black Loyalists.

questions.question: What does the Canadian flag look like?
questions.feedback: The Canadian flag is white with a red border on each end and a red maple leaf in the centre.
options: 1 White with a red border on each end and a red maple leaf in the centre
2 Red and white with provincial emblems
3 Red and white with a beaver
4 Red with a white maple leaf

questions.question: What is a voter information card?
questions.feedback: The National Register of Electors mails a card to everyone on the voters' list. This card tells you when and where you can vote.
options: 1 A form that tells you when and where to vote
2 Tells you what province to vote in
3 Tells you who the candidates are in your electoral district
4 A form that lets you know your voting time

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Canadian five-cent coin features an image of a ______.
questions.feedback: The beaver is on the five-cent coin.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The legal term for the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state is ______.
questions.feedback: Habeas corpus is the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state, originating from English common law.

questions.question: What is the largest religious affiliation in Canada?
questions.feedback: The great majority of Canadians identify as Christians. The largest religious affiliation is Catholic, followed by various Protestant churches.

questions.question: What part of the Constitution legally protects all Canadians' basic rights and freedoms?
questions.feedback: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms legally protects all Canadians' basic rights and freedoms.
options: 1 The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
4 The British Charter of Rights and Freedoms

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Women's ______ Movement was the effort by women to achieve the right to vote.
questions.feedback: The effort by women to achieve the right to vote is called the women's suffrage movement.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. "______! Our home and native land!" is the first line of Canada's national anthem.
questions.feedback: Canada's national anthem is called "O Canada," which starts with the phrase "O Canada! Our home and native land!".

questions.question: When did Queen Elizabeth II become Canada's queen?
questions.feedback: Queen Elizabeth II became the Queen of Canada in 1952.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. __________ was appointed Governor General of Canada and introduced responsible government in 1848-49.
questions.feedback: Lord Elgin was appointed Governor General of Canada and introduced responsible government in 1848-49.

questions.question: True or False? The Provincial Branch is one of the three branches of government.
questions.feedback: The three branches of government are the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches. There is no Provincial Branch.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the types of police in Canada?
questions.feedback: There are different types of police in Canada: Municipal police departments, provincial police forces, and the RCMP.

questions.question: Which party is the Official Opposition at the federal level?
questions.feedback: The current Official Opposition at the federal level is The Conservative Party.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. ______ is the largest producer of oil and gas in Canada.
questions.feedback: Alberta is the largest producer of oil and gas in Canada. The oil sands in northern Alberta are a major energy source.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. To be eligible to vote in Canadian federal elections, one must be a Canadian citizen, at least ___, and on the voters’ list.
questions.feedback: You must be at least 18 years old to vote in Canadian federal elections.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. __________ are civil cases involving small sums of money settled?
questions.feedback: Small claims courts handle civil cases involving small sums of money.

questions.question: How are Canadian Senators selected?
questions.feedback: Senators are appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister and serve until age 75.
options: 1 They are appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister
2 They are elected by the public
3 They are chosen by the provincial premiers
4 They are appointed by the King directly

questions.question: Who helped Upper Canada make the decision to stop slavery in 1793?
questions.feedback: Lieutenant Governor John Graves Simcoe was a Loyalist military officer and the first Lieutenant Governor of Canada. He was also the founder of the city of York, now Toronto.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The name “Canada” originates from “Kanata,” the Huron-Iroquois word for __________.
questions.feedback: "Kanata" means "village" in the Iroquoian language, from which the name Canada is derived.

questions.question: How many Black Loyalists came north to live in Canada?
questions.feedback: About 3,000 Black Loyalists came north to live in Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Canadian Coat of Arms’ motto is “A Mari Usque Ad Mare,” meaning __________.
questions.feedback: The national motto is "A Mari Usque Ad Mare," a Latin expression meaning "from sea to sea."
options: 2 From the sea to the ends of the earth
3 From the ocean to the sea
4 From the water to the earth

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The last spike of the Canadian Pacific Railway was driven in ________, completing the first transcontinental railway.
questions.feedback: In 1885, the last spike was driven, marking the completion of the railway connecting Eastern and Western Canada.

questions.question: What is the significance of the Statute of Westminster 1931 for Canada?
questions.feedback: The Statute of Westminster 1931 granted Canada full legal autonomy, making it equal in status to the United Kingdom.
options: 1 It granted full legal freedom from the UK
2 It established the Canadian Charter of Rights
4 It abolished the monarchy in Canada

questions.question: In which region do more than half the people in Canada live?
questions.feedback: More than half the people in Canada live in Quebec and Ontario, known as Central Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The capital city of Ontario, which is also Canada's largest city, is ___.
questions.feedback: Toronto is the capital city of Ontario and the largest city in Canada.

questions.question: How does a bill become a law?
questions.feedback: A bill becomes a law after approval by a majority in the House of Commons and Senate and, finally, the Governor General.
options: 1 Approval by a majority in the House of Commons and Senate and finally the Governor General
2 The Lieutenant Governor must approve the bill
3 The King must sign the bill
4 Approval by the Members of the Legislative Assembly

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Royal Anthem of Canada is __________.
questions.feedback: The Royal Anthem of Canada is “God Save the King (or Queen).” It can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honour the Sovereign.

questions.question: True or False? In Canada, men and women are equal under the law.
questions.feedback: In Canada, men and women are equal under the law.

questions.question: What is Canada’s national winter sport?
questions.feedback: Hockey is Canada’s most popular spectator sport and is considered the national winter sport.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Today, about half of First Nations people live on __________.
questions.feedback: About half of First Nations people live on reserve land.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The first elected representative assembly in Canada was in __________.
questions.feedback: In 1758, the first representative assembly was elected in Halifax.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Members of Parliament are __________.
questions.feedback: Members of Parliament are elected by voters in their local constituency (riding).
options: 1 Elected by voters in their local constituency (riding)
4 Elected by landowners and police chiefs

questions.question: True or False? Military service is compulsory in Canada.
questions.feedback: There is no mandatory military service in Canada. However, serving in the regular Canadian forces is a noble way to contribute to Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. In a federal election, you are not obligated to tell __________ who you voted for.
questions.feedback: You are not obligated to tell anyone who you voted for in a federal election.

questions.question: Which region of Canada is known for its fertile agricultural land and valuable energy resources?
questions.feedback: Manitoba, Saskatchewan, and Alberta are the Prairie Provinces, rich in energy resources and some of the most fertile farmland.

questions.question: Which province was the last to join Confederation in 1949?
questions.feedback: Newfoundland and Labrador joined Canada as the tenth province in 1949.

questions.question: What province did Lower Canada become?
questions.feedback: Lower Canada became Quebec, and the Quebecers are the people of Quebec.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Remembrance Day poppy is a symbol to remember the ______ of Canadians who have served or died in wars.
questions.feedback: The poppy symbolizes the sacrifice of Canadian military personnel in conflicts.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Sir Wilfrid Laurier was the first ______ Canadian Prime Minister.
questions.feedback: Sir Wilfrid Laurier was the first French Canadian Prime Minister, serving from 1896 to 1911.

questions.question: What does the term “responsible government” mean?
questions.feedback: Responsible government means the ministers of the Crown must have the support of a majority of elected representatives.
options: 1 The ministers of the Crown must have the support of a majority of the elected representatives in order to govern
2 All Canadians are responsible for each other
3 The Governor General is responsible for the actions of the Prime Minister
4 Each person in each electoral district is responsible for voting

questions.question: True or False? The US is Canada’s largest trading partner.
questions.feedback: Canada has a close relationship with the US, being each other's largest trading partners.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Canada has ______ territories and ______ provinces.
questions.feedback: Canada has three (3) territories and ten (10) provinces.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Victoria Cross is the highest honour awarded to Canadians for ___________.
questions.feedback: The Victoria Cross is awarded to Canadians for valour, which is great courage in the face of danger in battle.

questions.question: What is the significance of Remembrance Day in Canada?
questions.feedback: Remembrance Day honors Canadians who sacrificed their lives in military service.
options: 1 It commemorates Canadians who died in wars
2 It celebrates the end of World War II
3 It marks the founding of Canada

questions.question: True or False? The Charter of Rights and Freedoms protects Canadians' freedom of thought and belief.
questions.feedback: The Charter of Rights and Freedoms secures Canadians' freedom of conscience, religion, thought, and belief.

questions.question: True or False? Inuit make up about 6% of the Aboriginal population in Canada.
questions.feedback: Inuit constitute approximately 4% of the Aboriginal population, not 6%.

questions.question: What is the largest religious affiliation in Canada?
questions.feedback: The great majority of Canadians identify as Christians. The largest religious affiliation is Catholic, followed by various Protestant churches.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The __________ is a symbol of the Canadian government, the legislatures, the courts, police services, and the Canadian Forces.
questions.feedback: The Crown is a symbol of the Canadian government, the legislatures, the courts, police services, and the Canadian Forces.

questions.question: True or False? The RCMP is Canada's national police force.
questions.feedback: The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) serves as Canada's federal and national police service.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Canada’s justice system is based on the principle of __________ of innocence.
questions.feedback: Canada’s justice system is based on the principle of presumption of innocence.

questions.question: Which of the following documents secures Canadians’ freedom of conscience, religion, thought, and belief?
questions.feedback: The document that secures Canadians' freedom of conscience, religion, thought, and belief is The Charter of Rights and Freedoms.
options: 1 The Charter of Rights and Freedoms

questions.question: When was the Bank of Canada created?
questions.feedback: The Bank of Canada was created in 1934.

questions.question: True or False? The majority of Canadians live within 100 km of the U.S. border.
questions.feedback: Approximately 90% of Canadians live within 100 km of the U.S. border due to milder climate and trade.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The majority of Canada's Aboriginal population is composed of ______.
questions.feedback: First Nations make up about 65% of the Aboriginal population in Canada.

questions.question: How many speak French as their first language in Quebec?
questions.feedback: Nearly 8 million people live in Quebec, and more than 75% speak French as their first language.

questions.question: True or False? Sir John A. Macdonald served as Canada's first Prime Minister starting in 1863.
questions.feedback: Canada's first prime minister was Sir John A. Macdonald, who took office in 1867.

questions.question: What are the provinces of the Atlantic region?
questions.feedback: The provinces in the Atlantic region are Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island.
options: 1 Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island
2 Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island and Quebec
3 Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Quebec
4 Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Quebec, and Ontario

questions.question: Which country borders Canada in the south?
questions.feedback: Along the southern edge of Canada lies the Canada-United States boundary.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Following a federal election, the political party that secures the majority of seats in the __________ typically forms the government.
questions.feedback: After a federal election, the party with the most elected representatives in the House of Commons usually forms the new government.

questions.question: Who was the first French Canadian prime minister?
questions.feedback: Sir Wilfrid Laurier was the first French Canadian prime minister

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The current Governor General of Canada is __________.
questions.feedback: Mary Simon is the 30th Governor General of Canada. She started her role on July 26, 2021.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Canada’s largest trading partner is __________.
questions.feedback: Canada's largest trading partner is the United States. The two countries share one of the world's longest undefended borders and a highly integrated economy, with significant trade in goods and services flowing between them every day.

questions.question: Who was the Métis’ greatest military leader?
questions.feedback: Gabriel Dumont was the Métis’ greatest military leader, known for his role in the North-West Resistance of 1885.

questions.question: True or False? Serving on a jury is both a right and a responsibility of Canadian citizens.
questions.feedback: Serving on a jury is an essential civic duty and a fundamental right in Canada.

questions.question: How many First Nations communities are on reserve land?
questions.feedback: There are around 600 communities on reserve land and the other half live mainly in urban centres.

questions.question: True or False? Lake Superior, the largest freshwater lake by surface area, plays a significant role in Canada's freshwater ecosystem and international trade routes.
questions.feedback: Lake Superior is the largest freshwater lake in the world by surface area and is vital for both the ecosystem and as part of international trade routes between Canada and the United States.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Central Canada, comprising Ontario and Quebec, contributes to over __________ through its industrial and manufacturing sectors.
questions.feedback: Central Canada is the industrial and manufacturing heartland, with Ontario and Quebec producing more than 75% of Canada’s manufactured goods, significantly contributing to the GDP.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. In Canadian federal elections, citizens elect Members of Parliament (MPs) to represent them in the __________, which is responsible for legislative processes.
questions.feedback: Canadians vote for Members of Parliament to represent them in the House of Commons, which plays a key role in creating and passing laws.

questions.question: Men and women get the same education in Canada:
questions.feedback: Men and women are equal in Canada under the law.
options: 1 Because men and women are equal under the law in Canada
2 Because Canada is a free country
3 Because education is free in Canada
4 Because people respect multiculturalism in Canada

questions.question: True or false? You have to do military service in Canada as a citizen.
questions.feedback: Serving in the regular Canadian forces (navy, army, and air force) is a noble way to contribute to Canada and an excellent career choice.

questions.question: What are the people who speak French as a first language called?
questions.feedback: After the First World War, Canada chose an official Coat of Arms. The national motto is A Mari Usque Ad Mare. This is a Latin expression that means from sea to sea.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Victoria Cross, awarded for extraordinary valor, is the highest military decoration a Canadian can receive, often recognized for __________.
questions.feedback: The Victoria Cross is awarded for extraordinary bravery and valor in the face of the enemy, making it the highest military honor in Canada.
options: 1 Bravery in the face of the enemy

questions.question: Which of the following is not in the Maritimes?
questions.feedback: The provinces on the eastern side of Canada - Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Prince Edward Island - are called the Maritime Provinces.

questions.question: Who was the initial cartographer to create a map of Canada's eastern coastline?
questions.feedback: John Cabot was the first to draw a map of the east coast of Canada.

questions.question: True or False? The moniker "Great Dominion" has been used in Canadian literature to emphasize Canada's status within the British Empire during the 19th century.
questions.feedback: Poets and songwriters have referred to Canada as "The Great Dominion," highlighting its status and vastness within the British Empire during the 19th century.

questions.question: What part of the Constitution legally protects the basic rights and freedoms of all Canadians?
questions.feedback: Magna Carta, the Great Charter of Rights and Freedoms, was signed in 1215 in England, and it includes Canadian Rights and Freedoms.
options: 1 The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
4 The British Charter of Rights and Freedoms

questions.question: When was The Canadian Pacific Railway finished?
questions.feedback: The Canadian Pacific Railway was finished in 1885 and became a powerful symbol of unity.

questions.question: True or false? The Government of Canada apologized for the Head Tax in 2002.
questions.feedback: The Head Tax was a race-based fee charged to Chinese who entered Canada. In 2006, the Government of Canada apologized for this discriminatory policy.

questions.question: What are the three main groups of Aboriginal peoples?
questions.feedback: The term Aboriginal peoples refers to three groups: The Indian (First Nations People), The Inuit and The Métis
options: 3 United Empire Loyalists, Métis and Inuit

questions.question: Fill in the blank. In the context of Canadian governance, “responsible government” requires that the __________ support the majority of elected representatives in the House of Commons.
questions.feedback: Responsible government means that the ministers of the Crown must have the support of a majority of the elected representatives to govern effectively.

questions.question: True or false? The name “Canada” comes from "Kanata", the Huron-Iroquois word for vast.
questions.feedback: Kanata means "village" in the Iroquoian language. By the 1550s, the name Canada began appearing on maps.

questions.question: The “right to challenge unlawful detention by the state” is also known as:
questions.feedback: Habeas corpus is the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state, and it has come from English common law.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Taking care of oneself and one’s family, serving on a jury, and protecting the environment are __________.
questions.feedback: Responsibilities of Canadian citizenship include taking care of oneself and one’s family, serving on a jury, and protecting the environment. These responsibilities are part of the commitment that comes with being a Canadian citizen and contribute to the well-being and sustainability of Canadian society.
options: 2 Offences under the Canadian Criminal Code
3 Responsibilities for some people, but not for others

questions.question: Fill in the blank. ________ workers built the Canadian Pacific Railway.
questions.feedback: The project was paid for by American and British investors, and both Europeans and Chinese built it.

questions.question: True or false? Gay and lesbian Canadians have the full protection of and equal treatment under the law.
questions.feedback: Gay and lesbian Canadians are protected under the law; they are treated the same as other Canadians; they can get married.

questions.question: How many Canadians served in the First World War?
questions.feedback: More than 600,000 Canadians served in the first World War.

questions.question: When were Aboriginal people allowed to vote?
questions.feedback: Aboriginal people were allowed to vote in 1960.

questions.question: What is British Columbia's largest ethnic community?
questions.feedback: BC has large Asian communities, and Chinese and Punjabi are the most-spoken languages in the cities, after English.

questions.question: The highest court in Canada is:
questions.feedback: Canada’s highest court is called the Supreme Court of Canada.

questions.question: What does the Canadian flag look like?
questions.feedback: The Canadian flag is white with a red border on each end and a red maple leaf in the centre.
options: 1 White with a red border on each end and a red maple leaf in the centre
2 Red and white with provincial emblems
3 Red and white with a beaver
4 Red with a white maple leaf

questions.question: Who was Canada's most outstanding soldier in the First World War?
questions.feedback: Canada's greatest soldier in the First World War was General Sir Arthur Currie.

questions.question: Which political party is currently in power at the federal level?
questions.feedback: The Liberal Party is currently in power at the federal level of the government.

questions.question: Which company did King Charles II allow to look for fur?
questions.feedback: In 1670, King Charles II of England decided that the fur trade company called the Hudson’s Bay Company was allowed to look for fur in all of the land that had water flowing into Hudson Bay.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The extension of federal voting rights to women in Canada was championed by __________, who played a pivotal role in this social reform.
questions.feedback: Sir Robert Borden was instrumental in granting women the right to vote in federal elections, advancing gender equality in Canadian politics.

questions.question: The Remembrance Day poppy symbolizes:
questions.feedback: The Remembrance Day poppy symbolizes the sacrifice of Canadians who have served or died in wars up to the present day
options: 1 The sacrifice of Canadians who have served or died in wars
2 The Prime Ministers who have died
3 The Confederation and the its leaders
4 The Sovereign and leaders of the government

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The largest and busiest port in Canada, facilitating significant international trade, is the __________.
questions.feedback: The Port of Vancouver is Canada’s largest and busiest port, serving as a critical hub for international trade and maritime activities on the Pacific coast.

questions.question: Who played a pivotal role in assisting the Loyalists in relocating from the United States to Nova Scotia and Quebec during the years 1782 and 1783?
questions.feedback: Sir Guy Carleton was British. He was also called Lord Dorchester. He helped the people who lived in the United States and wanted to stay loyal to the British queen. He helped these Loyalists move from the United States to Nova Scotia and Quebec in 1782 and 1783.

questions.question: Which day is recognized as Canada’s national day of celebration?
The Peace Tower, a prominent feature of the Parliament Hill in Ottawa, was completed in 1927 to commemorate which specific group of individuals?
questions.feedback: In 1927, the Peace Tower was completed to remember the soldiers who died in World War I.
options: 1 The soldiers who died in World War I

questions.question: What did Sir Étienne-Paschal Taché, Sir George-Étienne Cartier and Sir John A. Macdonald become?
questions.feedback: Sir Étienne-Paschal Taché and George-Étienne Cartier were two reformers who became Fathers of Confederation. Sir John A. Macdonald, a former member of the voluntary government militia in Upper Canada, also became one of the Fathers of Confederation.

questions.question: Which province in Canada is the smallest in land size?
questions.feedback: Prince Edward Island (P.E.I.) is the smallest province, known for its beaches, red soil and agriculture, especially potatoes.

questions.question: Who represents King Charles II in the province of Quebec?
questions.feedback: The Sovereign’s representative in the provinces is called Lieutenant-Governor.

questions.question: What two groups consider and review bills?
questions.feedback: The Senate and the House of Commons consider and review bills.
options: 1 The Senate and the House of Commons
4 The Cabinet and the House of Commons

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Among Canada’s three territories, __________ is NOT one of them.
questions.feedback: Nordic Territories is not a Canadian territory. The actual territories are the Northwest Territories, Yukon Territory, and Nunavut.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered a branch of the government?
questions.feedback: The Executive, Legislative and Judicial branches work together in the government.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Atlantic provinces include ________.
questions.feedback: The Atlantic provinces are located on the east coast of Canada, known for their maritime culture and economy, which includes fishing and shipping. Visualizing a map can help solidify which provinces belong to this region. Newfoundland and Labrador, for example, are often grouped together as a unique part of Canada’s history and geography.
options: 1 New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and Newfoundland and Labrador
2 Quebec, New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, and Newfoundland and Labrador
3 Newfoundland and Labrador, Nova Scotia, Prince Edward Island, and Quebec
4 Prince Edward Island, Quebec, New Brunswick, and Ontario

questions.question: What are two fundamental freedoms protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?
questions.feedback: Canadians enjoy four (4) fundamental freedoms: Freedom of conscience and religion, freedom of thought, belief, and opinion and expression, including freedom of speech and of the press, freedom of peaceful assembly, and freedom of association.
options: 1 Freedom of conscience and religion, and Freedom of association
3 Aboriginal peoples' rights, and to volunteer
4 Equality rights, and to care for Canada's heritage

questions.question: Who led thousands of Loyalist Mohawk Indians into Canada?
questions.feedback: Joseph Brant led thousands of Loyalist Mohawk Indians into Canada. These loyalists came from Dutch, German, British, Scandinavian, Aboriginal, and other origins and had different religious backgrounds.

questions.question: True or false? The highest mountain in Canada is Mount Logan, located in the Yukon.
Which of the following is in NAFTA?
questions.feedback: In 1994, Mexico, U.S.A. and Canada became partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA).

questions.question: Who is entitled to vote in Canadian federal elections?
questions.feedback: You are eligible to vote in a federal election or to cast a ballot in a federal referendum if you are a Canadian citizen who is at least 18 years old on voting day and on the voters’ list.
options: 1 A Canadian citizen who is at least 18 years old on voting day and on the voters’ list.
2 A Canadian citizen who is at least 16 years old on voting day and on the voters’ list.
3 Anyone living in Canada who is at least 18 years old on voting day and on the voters’ list.
4 Anyone living in Canada who is at least 16 years old on voting day and on the voters’ list.

questions.question: When did the Confederation take place?
questions.feedback: Canada officially became a country in 1867, known as Confederation. This is when four provinces—Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia—joined together to form the Dominion of Canada under the British North America Act. Remembering this date is essential as it marks the founding moment of modern Canada.

questions.question: In Canada, military service is not compulsory. True or false?
questions.feedback: There is no mandatory military service in Canada. However, serving in the regular Canadian forces (navy, army, and air force) is a noble way to contribute to Canada.

questions.question: Alberta is recognized as the largest producer of oil and gas in Canada primarily due to its extensive reserves of which natural resource?
questions.feedback: Alberta is Canada’s largest producer of oil and natural gas, contributing significantly to the country’s economy. The province’s oil sands, particularly around Fort McMurray, are one of the largest reserves in the world.

questions.question: Which of the following anthems is officially designated as the Royal Anthem of Canada, performed to honor the Sovereign during state occasions?
questions.feedback: The Royal Anthem of Canada is “God Save the King (or Queen)”. It is performed to honor the Sovereign on formal state occasions.

questions.question: Jean-Paul Riopelle was part of a group called Les Automatistes. True or false?
questions.feedback: In Quebec, the most famous abstract art painter was Jean-Paul Riopelle. He was part of a group from Quebec called Les Automatistes.

questions.question: The term "Great Charter of Freedoms" historically refers to which foundational document signed in 1215 that established key legal principles in England and influenced Canadian rights frameworks?
questions.feedback: The Great Charter of Freedoms is another name for the Magna Carta, signed in 1215, which laid the groundwork for modern legal systems, including those in Canada.

questions.question: What key provision was established by the Official Languages Act of 1969 in Canada?
questions.feedback: The Official Languages Act of 1969 guaranteed French-language rights and services within the federal government, promoting bilingualism at the national level.
options: 1 French-language rights and services in the federal government
2 Both English and French-language rights and services in the federal government
3 Bilingual education policies across all provinces
4 French-language rights and services exclusively in Quebec

questions.question: Who were the first people to live in Canada?
questions.feedback: The Aboriginal peoples were the first people to live in Canada. They lived and worked in Canada long before the French or British came.

questions.question: Who are the Acadians?
questions.feedback: The Acadians are the descendants of French colonists who began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces in 1604.
options: 1 They are descendants of French colonists who came to Canada in 1604
2 They are descendants of English colonists who came to Canada in 1763
3 They are descendants of English colonists who came to Canada in 1604
4 They are descendants of French colonists who came to Canada in 1763

questions.question: Which of the following rights is not guaranteed by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms?
questions.feedback: While environmental issues are important, they are not explicitly covered in the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. The Charter guarantees fundamental rights such as freedom of speech, religion, and the right to vote. This distinction is important when studying Canadian law and governance.

questions.question: Who do Members of Parliament represent?
questions.feedback: Members of Parliament represent everyone who lives in his or her electoral district.
options: 1 Everyone who lives in his or her electoral district
2 Only Canadians living in Central Canada
3 All of the Canadians living in the north
4 Canadians living in the province in which he/she was elected

questions.question: Which of the following is not a foundation of Canada’s legal system?
questions.feedback: Canada's legal system is based on the rule of law, freedom under the law, democratic principles, and due process.

questions.question: What are the people who speak French as a first language called?
questions.feedback: People who speak French as a first language are called Francophones. There are about 7 million of them.

questions.question: What is due process?
questions.feedback: The Canadian justice system has a very organized way of ensuring that everyone has fair treatment, with all of their legal rights. This is called due process.
options: 1 It is an organized way of ensuring that everyone has just and fair treatment with all of their legal rights.
2 It is a random and fair way of ensuring that some people have just and fair treatment, with all of their legal rights.

questions.question: What was the significance of the Battle of Vimy Ridge during World War I for Canada?
questions.feedback: The Battle of Vimy Ridge in 1917 is often regarded as a defining moment for Canada. It was the first time all four divisions of the Canadian Corps fought together, and their success became a symbol of Canadian pride and achievement, marking the country’s emergence as a more independent and self-reliant nation.
options: 1 It was a battle that defined Canada as an independent nation
2 It was the first major defeat of the Canadian Army
3 It was the first time Canadian soldiers fought overseas
4 It was the final battle of World War I

questions.question: The city originally named York, founded in 1793 by Lieutenant Governor John Graves Simcoe, is now known as:
questions.feedback: The city of York, founded by Lieutenant Governor John Graves Simcoe in 1793, was renamed Toronto, becoming the largest city in Canada.

questions.question: In Canada, forced marriage is:
questions.feedback: No one can force anybody to marry someone else (forced marriage) in Canada under the law.

questions.question: In which year did the Statute of Westminster give Canada full control over its foreign policy?
questions.feedback: The Statute of Westminster, passed in 1931, gave Canada and other Commonwealth countries control over their foreign policy and legal independence from Britain. This was a major step toward full sovereignty, leading to the eventual patriation of the Constitution in 1982.

questions.question: What year was the Canadian Bill of Rights introduced?
questions.feedback: The Canadian Bill of Rights was introduced in 1960 by Prime Minister John Diefenbaker. Although it was not as comprehensive as the Charter of Rights and Freedoms (1982), it was the first federal law to protect human rights and freedoms in Canada. Remembering this year helps place Canada’s legal evolution in context.

questions.question: What was the name of the provinces of Upper Canada, Lower Canada and the Atlantic colonies?
questions.feedback: The name for the provinces of Upper Canada, Lower Canada, and the Atlantic colonies was British North America.

questions.question: What is the highest court in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada’s highest court is called the Supreme Court of Canada.

questions.question: Who are the founding peoples of Canada?
questions.feedback: There are 3 groups of people who helped to start Canada: The Aboriginal people, the French, and the British

questions.question: Prisons do not have an essential role in punishing criminals and deterring crime.
questions.feedback: Prisons do have an essential role in punishing criminals and deterring crime.

questions.question: What province did Upper Canada become? Was it Protestant or Catholic?
questions.feedback: Upper Canada later became Ontario, and it had mostly English-speaking people who were Protestant and were loyal to Britain.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. An essential sector of Yukon's economy, contributing significantly to its GDP, is __________.
questions.feedback: Mining is a crucial part of Yukon's economy, driving economic growth and providing employment opportunities.

questions.question: How many electoral districts does Canada have?
questions.feedback: Canada has 338 electoral districts, each representing a seat in the House of Commons.

questions.question: What did Canada Day use to be called?
questions.feedback: Canada currently has 338 federal electoral districts. However, the official handbook indicates the number of electoral districts as 308, as it was last updated in 2012.

questions.question: Who is responsible for signing bills into law in Canada?
questions.feedback: In Canada’s constitutional monarchy, the Governor General, who represents the monarch, signs bills into law through a process called Royal Assent. While the Prime Minister leads the government, the Governor General plays a ceremonial role in the legislative process, which is important to remember for understanding how Canada’s political system functions.

questions.question: What is the Commonwealth?
questions.feedback: The Commonwealth is a group of 54 countries that are loyal to the King (or Queen).
options: 1 A group of 54 countries who are loyal to the King
2 A group of 54 countries who are loyal to Canada
3 A group of 13 countries who are loyal to the UN
4 A group of 13 countries who are loyal to the King

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The administrative center of the Northwest Territories, serving as the hub for government and services, is __________.
questions.feedback: Yellowknife is the capital of the Northwest Territories, functioning as the central hub for its administration and services.

questions.question: Which of the following provinces was not one of the original provinces that formed Confederation in 1867?
questions.feedback: Manitoba joined Confederation in 1870, three years after the original provinces—Ontario, Quebec, New Brunswick, and Nova Scotia—came together in 1867.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The official summer sport in Canada, which has historical roots with Aboriginal peoples, is __________.
questions.feedback: Lacrosse is recognized as the official summer sport in Canada and was first played by Aboriginal peoples, reflecting its cultural significance.

questions.question: True or false? In Canada, Senators are elected.
questions.feedback: The Senators are appointed by the Governor General.

questions.question: When Canadians vote during a federal election, where does the winning candidate need to go?
questions.feedback: Canadians vote in elections for the people they want to represent them in the House of Commons in Ottawa.

questions.question: Who does the Prime Minister have to ask if he wants an earlier election?
questions.feedback: Prime Minister may ask the Governor General to hold an earlier election.

questions.question: True or false? Military service is compulsory in Canada.
questions.feedback: There is no mandatory military service in Canada. However, serving in the regular Canadian forces (navy, army, and air force) is a noble way to contribute to Canada.

questions.question: Who was responsible for selecting Ottawa as the capital city of Canada in 1857, recognizing its strategic location?
questions.feedback: In 1857, Queen Victoria chose Ottawa to be the capital of Canada due to its strategic and neutral location between English and French-speaking regions.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The region encompassing Ottawa and its surrounding areas, serving as the administrative and political hub of Canada, is known as the __________.
questions.feedback: The area around Ottawa, including the city itself, is referred to as the National Capital Region, housing key government institutions.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. A group of Canadian landscape painters in the 1920s who painted the wilderness in Canada was called ______.
questions.feedback: The most famous Canadian visual artists are the Group of Seven, who painted the wilderness.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the three key facts about Canada’s system of government?
questions.feedback: Canada is a federal state, a parliamentary democracy, and a constitutional monarchy.

questions.question: True or False? The Canadian Pacific Railway was completed in 1912.
questions.feedback: The Canadian Pacific Railway was completed in 1885, not 1912. This railway was instrumental in connecting Canada from coast to coast, and its completion marked a significant moment in Canadian nation-building and economic expansion.

questions.question: True or False? Alexander Graham Bell is credited with conceptualizing and inventing the telephone, revolutionizing global communication.
questions.feedback: Alexander Graham Bell is recognized for his pioneering work in developing the telephone, significantly advancing global communication technology.

questions.question: What percentage of the Nunavut population is Inuit?
questions.feedback: The Nunavut population is about 85% Inuit.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. _______ steps are required before a bill becomes law in Canada.
questions.feedback: There are seven steps before a bill becomes law in Canada.

questions.question: True or false? Ottawa is the fourth-largest metropolitan area in Canada.
questions.feedback: Ottawa is indeed Canada’s fourth-largest metropolitan area.

questions.question: When do Members of the House of Commons debate the ideas in the bill?
questions.feedback: They debate the ideas in the bill in the Second Reading.

questions.question: True or false? The Canadian Crown refers to a physical crown owned by the King.
questions.feedback: The Canadian Crown is not referring to a physical crown, but to the monarchy (King or Queen) and acts as a symbol of Parliament, the legislatures, the courts, police services and the armed forces.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. _______ is known as the industrial and manufacturing heartland of Canada.
questions.feedback: Central Canada is the industrial and manufacturing heartland, with Quebec and Ontario producing over 75% of Canada’s manufactured goods.

questions.question: What was an era of rapid change in Quebec when many Quebecers tried to separate from Canada called?
questions.feedback: Many Quebecers tried to separate from Canada in the 1960s. This was called the Quiet Revolution.

questions.question: True or false? America was able to conquer Canada.
questions.feedback: Despite multiple attempts by American forces, particularly during the War of 1812, America was not able to conquer Canada.

questions.question: What do you mark on a federal election ballot?
questions.feedback: You mark an “X” in the circle next to the name of the candidate of your choice on a federal election ballot.

questions.question: Which group was well established in the territories of modern-day Canada before Europeans arrived?
questions.feedback: Aboriginal peoples, including First Nations, Inuit, and Métis, were well established in the territories of modern-day Canada long before the arrival of Europeans. These Indigenous groups have a rich history, culture, and connection to the land that predates European colonization by thousands of years.
options: 4 No one was here before Europeans

questions.question: What percentage of the goods that Canada exports go to the United States?
questions.feedback: Over 3/4 (75%) of Canada's exports go to the U.S.A. Canada and the U.S.A. have the largest bilateral trading relationship in the world.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. “Responsible government” means that the ministers of the Crown must have the support of a _________ of the elected representatives to govern.
questions.feedback: Responsible government requires that ministers have the support of a majority of elected representatives.

questions.question: The Governor General is appointed by the Canadian Parliament.
questions.feedback: The Governor General is appointed by the monarch on the advice of the Prime Minister, not by Parliament. Understanding the appointment process helps clarify the ceremonial role of the Governor General in Canada’s system of government.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. _______ of Canadians currently have jobs in service industries.
questions.feedback: More than 75% of working Canadians now have jobs in service industries.

questions.question: What is British Columbia's biggest industry?
questions.feedback: Half of all the goods produced in BC are forestry products, including lumber, newsprint, and pulp and paper products.

questions.question: What does a non-confidence vote lead to?
questions.feedback: If a majority of the elected representatives vote that they are not confident that the cabinet ministers are doing their job, then the government is defeated and an election is held.

questions.question: What is British Columbia's biggest ethnic community?
questions.feedback: BC has large Asian communities, and Chinese and Punjabi are the most-spoken languages in the cities, after English.

questions.question: Which Canadian Prime Minister is known for patriating the Constitution in 1982?
questions.feedback: In 1982, Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau patriated the Canadian Constitution, bringing it fully under Canadian control and enshrining the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. This move was significant in establishing Canadian legal independence from Britain.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. __________ are appointed on the advice of the Prime Minister.
questions.feedback: In Canada, Senators are appointed on the advice of the Prime Minister. They serve in the Senate, the upper house of Parliament, where they review legislation, represent regional interests, and provide a check on the elected House of Commons.

questions.question: Who discovered insulin, a hormone that helps to treat diabetes?
questions.feedback: Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best discovered insulin, a hormone that helps to treat diabetes. This invention has saved 16 million lives worldwide.
options: 1 Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best
4 Charles Best and Dr. Wilder Penfield

questions.question: True or false? The North of Canada constitutes half of the country's land mass.
questions.feedback: The North (Northwest Territories, Nunavut, and Yukon) makes up one third of Canada’s land mass, not half.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Between 1755 and 1763, the forced removal of the Acadians from Canada is known as the __________.
questions.feedback: There was a war between Britain and France between 1755 and 1763. During this time, more than two-thirds of the Acadians living in this part of Canada were forced to leave. This is called the Great Upheaval.

questions.question: When did the USA vs. Canada war end?
questions.feedback: The war ended in 1814. America was not able to conquer Canada.

questions.question: Upper and Lower Canada were united to create:
questions.feedback: In 1840, Upper and Lower Canada were united as the Province of Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. N.W.T. is an abbreviation for the __________.
questions.feedback: N.W.T. stands for Northwest Territories.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. In Canada, __________ have the role of settling disputes between individuals.
questions.feedback: In Canada, the courts are responsible for settling disputes between individuals. The judiciary operates independently of the executive and legislative branches, ensuring fair and impartial resolution of conflicts according to the law.
options: 2 Officers from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)

questions.question: True or False? The British North America Act was passed by the British Parliament.
questions.feedback: The British North America Act, which established Canada as a Confederation, was indeed passed by the British Parliament. It laid the groundwork for Canada’s federal structure and governance, and it is essential to know its origins.

questions.question: Who makes the voters' list?
questions.feedback: Elections Canada makes the voters' list because it is not associated with any of the political parties.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Canada started free trade with the United States in _____.
questions.feedback: In 1988, Canada started free trade with the United States.

questions.question: Which province was the first British North American colony to attain fully responsible government in 1847-48?
questions.feedback: Nova Scotia was the first British North American colony to attain full responsible government in 1847-48.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the freedoms that Canadians enjoy?
questions.feedback: Canadians enjoy four (4) fundamental freedoms: Freedom of conscience and religion, freedom of thought, belief, and opinion and expression, including freedom of speech and of the press, freedom of peaceful assembly, and freedom of association.
options: 2 Freedom of speech and of the press

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The capital city of New Brunswick is __________.
questions.feedback: New Brunswick’s capital is Fredericton.

questions.question: When did the United States attack Canada?
questions.feedback: The United States attacked Canada in June of 1812.

questions.question: When called to do so, serving on a jury is a:
questions.feedback: When called to do so, you are legally required to serve on a jury.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Major-General Sir Isaac Brock captured the city of __________ during his military campaign.
questions.feedback: Major-General Sir Isaac Brock captured the city of Detroit but was later killed near Niagara Falls.

questions.question: What was the Statute of Westminster of 1931?
questions.feedback: The Statute of Westminster (1931) was a key moment in Canada’s path to full independence, as it allowed Canada to make its own laws without requiring approval from Britain, especially concerning foreign policy. It’s a precursor to the final patriation of the Constitution in 1982.
options: 1 A law granting Canada control over its foreign policy and legal autonomy from Britain
2 A declaration of Canada’s independence from Britain
3 A law establishing the Canadian Senate
4 A treaty between Indigenous peoples and the Canadian government

questions.question: Why can men and women get the same education in Canada?
questions.feedback: Men and women are equal in Canada under the law.
options: 1 Because men and women are equal under the law in Canada
2 Because Canada is a free country
3 Because education is free in Canada
4 Because people respect multiculturalism in Canada

questions.question: True or False? You can vote in a federal election only on the day of the election.
questions.feedback: In Canada, you can vote in a federal election on election day, during advance polling days, by mail, or at an Elections Canada office before election day. These options are provided to ensure that all eligible voters have the opportunity to cast their vote.

questions.question: Which province is in the most easterly part of North America?
questions.feedback: Newfoundland and Labrador is the most easterly part of North America, and it has its own time zone.

questions.question: Canada has three territories, and how many provinces?
questions.feedback: Canada has three territories and ten provinces.

questions.question: True or False? You can also be added to the voters’ list on the day of the election.
questions.feedback: You are able to request to be added to the voters’ list on the day of the election.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. __________ was appointed Governor General of Canada and introduced responsible government in 1848-49.
questions.feedback: Lord Elgin was appointed Governor General of Canada and introduced responsible government in 1848-49.

questions.question: True or False? The Peace Tower was completed to commemorate Canadian soldiers who died in World War I.
questions.feedback: In 1927, the Peace Tower was completed to remember the soldiers who died in World War I.

questions.question: When was Canada officially formed as a Dominion?
questions.feedback: Dominion of Canada was officially born on July 1, 1867.

questions.question: Which war saw Canada emerge as a key player in the global arena, gaining international respect?
questions.feedback: Canada’s significant contributions during World War II, including its participation in D-Day and the liberation of Europe, marked its emergence as an independent force on the world stage.

questions.question: Canada has three territories and how many provinces?
questions.feedback: Canada has three territories and ten provinces.

questions.question: Why would you play the Royal Anthem of Canada?
questions.feedback: The Royal Anthem of Canada can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honour the Sovereign.

questions.question: True or False? Helping others in the community is one of many responsibilities that Canadian citizens have.
questions.feedback: Helping others in the community is one of many responsibilities that Canadian citizens have.

questions.question: Who were the first people to live in Canada?
questions.feedback: The Aboriginal peoples were the first people to live in Canada. They lived and worked in Canada long before the French or British came.

questions.question: Which group was well established in the territories of modern-day Canada before Europeans arrived?
questions.feedback: Aboriginal peoples, including First Nations, Inuit, and Métis, were well established in the territories of modern-day Canada long before European explorers and settlers arrived. They had diverse cultures, languages, and traditions that have significantly shaped the history and identity of Canada.
options: 2 No one was here before Europeans

questions.question: You can also be added to the voters’ list on the day of the election.
questions.feedback: You are able to request to be added to the voters’ list on the day of the election.

questions.question: Who is considered the father of Manitoba and a leader of the Métis people?
questions.feedback: Louis Riel led the Red River Rebellion and played a key role in the establishment of Manitoba as a province in 1870. He is a controversial yet iconic figure in Canadian history, especially among the Métis people, for whom he fought to protect their rights and culture.

questions.question: Who led thousands of Loyalist Mohawk Indians into Canada?
questions.feedback: Joseph Brant led thousands of Loyalist Mohawk Indians into Canada. These loyalists came from Dutch, German, British, Scandinavian, Aboriginal, and other origins, and had different religious backgrounds.

questions.question: Who was Sir Louis-Hippolyte La Fontaine in Canadian history?
questions.feedback: Sir Louis-Hippolyte La Fontaine became the first leader of a responsible government in Canada in 1849.
options: 1 The first leader of a responsible government in Canada
2 The first Governor General of Canada
4 The first Father of the Constitution

questions.question: What is the significance of the discovery of insulin by Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best?
questions.feedback: Sir Frederick Banting and Charles Best discovered insulin, a hormone that helps to treat diabetes. This invention has saved 16 million lives worldwide.
options: 1 Treats diabetes which has saved millions of lives worldwide
3 Saves the lives of people with heart disease
4 Saves the lives of people with eating disorders

questions.question: Which Aboriginal group was (historically) the enemy of the Algonquin, Montagnais and Huron?
questions.feedback: Champlain joined his colony with some Aboriginal groups: the Algonquin, Montagnais and Huron. These groups had a history of being enemies with another Aboriginal group, the Iroquois.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. __________ are appointed on the advice of the Prime Minister.
questions.feedback: In Canada, Senators are appointed on the advice of the Prime Minister. They serve in the Senate, the upper house of Parliament, where they review legislation, represent regional interests, and provide a check on the elected House of Commons.

questions.question: Where did the British defeat the French in 1759?
questions.feedback: In 1759, the British defeated the French at an important battle. This battle was near Quebec City, on the Plains of Abraham.

questions.question: What is the list of voters made by Elections Canada called?
questions.feedback: The list made by Elections Canada is called the National Register of Electors.

questions.question: What was the purpose of the Quiet Revolution in Quebec during the 1960s?
questions.feedback: The Quiet Revolution was a period of rapid social, political, and economic change in Quebec. It sought to modernize Quebec society, reduce the power of the Catholic Church, and establish Quebec as a more secular and progressive society.
options: 1 To reduce the influence of the Catholic Church and modernize Quebec society
2 To support Quebec’s independence from Canada
3 To promote French as the sole official language of Canada
4 To unite all provinces in economic cooperation

questions.question: Fill in the blank. A law is called __________ before it is formally passed in Canada.
questions.feedback: A bill is a proposed (suggested) law that is introduced in either the House of Commons or the Senate.

questions.question: “A Mari Usque Ad Mare” is the the Canadian Coat of Arms and motto, which means:
questions.feedback: After the First World War, Canada chose an official Coat of Arms. The national motto is A Mari Usque Ad Mare. This is a Latin expression that means from sea to sea.
options: 2 From the sea to the ends of the earth
3 From the ocean to the sea
4 From the water to the earth

questions.question: Where do more than half the Canadians live?
questions.feedback: More than half the people in Canada live in Quebec and Ontario, known as Central Canada.

questions.question: True or False? Many of Canada's exports are natural resource commodities.
Who do Members of Parliament represent?
questions.feedback: Members of Parliament represent everyone who lives in his or her electoral district.
options: 1 Everyone who lives in his or her electoral district
2 Only Canadians living in Central Canada
3 All of the Canadians living in the north
4 Canadians living in the province in which he/she was elected

questions.question: Which one of the places below would not be considered a national historic site?
questions.feedback: National historic sites in Canada are designated for their cultural, historical, or archaeological significance. While battlefields, sacred spaces, and archaeological sites often meet these criteria, a food bank would not typically be considered a national historic site.

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the three groups of awards that honour Canadians?
questions.feedback: Awards honour outstanding citizens and are divided into the following groups: orders, decorations, and medals.

questions.question: Who are the Acadians?
questions.feedback: The Acadians are the descendants of French colonists who began settling in what are now the Maritime provinces in 1604.
options: 1 They are descendants of French colonists who came to Canada in 1604
2 They are descendants of English colonists who came to Canada in 1763
3 They are descendants of English colonists who came to Canada in 1604
4 They are descendants of French colonists who came to Canada in 1763

questions.question: Which of the following are the three main industries in Canada's economy?
questions.feedback: Service, manufacturing, and natural resource industries are the three main industries in Canada's economy.
options: 1 Service, manufacturing, and natural resource industries
3 Entertainment, manufacturing, and natural resource industries

questions.question: Which of the following is not one of the three parts of Parliament?
questions.feedback: Three parts of parliament are the Sovereign, the Senate and the House of Commons.

questions.question: True or False? The Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP) enforces federal laws.
questions.feedback: The RCMP enforces federal laws

questions.question: True or False? The North takes up one-third of Canada’s landmass.
questions.feedback: The Northwest Territories, Nunavut, and Yukon contain one-third of Canada’s landmass.

questions.question: In which year did the Statute of Westminster give Canada full control over its foreign policy?
questions.feedback: The Statute of Westminster, passed in 1931, gave Canada and other Commonwealth countries control over their foreign policy and legal independence from Britain. This was a major step toward full sovereignty, leading to the eventual patriation of the Constitution in 1982.

questions.question: What do you call the Sovereign’s representative in the provinces?
questions.feedback: The Sovereign’s representative in the provinces is called Lieutenant-Governor.

questions.question: How does a bill become a law?
questions.feedback: A bill becomes a law after approval by a majority in the House of Commons and Senate and, finally the Governor General.
options: 1 Approval by a majority in the House of Commons and Senate and finally the Governor General
2 The Lieutenant Governor must approve the bill
3 The King must sign the bill
4 Approval by the Members of the Legislative Assembly

questions.question: Since when has Canada been a constitutional monarchy?
questions.feedback: Canada has been a constitutional monarchy since 1867 (Confederation).

questions.question: The group of men who negotiated the creation of Canada’s Confederation in 1867 are known as the __________.
questions.feedback: The Fathers of Confederation were the political leaders who worked to create the Dominion of Canada in 1867. Their efforts led to the formation of Canada’s first provinces under the British North America Act.

questions.question: Which federal political party is currently in power?
questions.feedback: The Liberal Party is currently in power at the federal level of the government.

questions.question: True or False? Military service is compulsory in Canada.
questions.feedback: There is no mandatory military service in Canada. However, serving in the regular Canadian forces (navy, army, and air force) is a noble way to contribute to Canada.

questions.question: Which of the following is one of Canada's three territories?
questions.feedback: Canada's three territories are: Northwest Territories, Yukon Territory, Nunavut

questions.question: Which one of the places below would not be considered a national historic site?
questions.feedback: National historic sites in Canada are designated for their cultural, historical, or archaeological significance. While battlefields, sacred spaces, and archaeological sites can hold such significance, a food bank does not typically meet the criteria for designation as a national historic site.

questions.question: Which was the last province to join Canada?
questions.feedback: Newfoundland was the last province to join Canada.

questions.question: Who are the Quebecers?
questions.feedback: The Quebecers are the people of Quebec.

questions.question: True or false? Royal Anthem of Canada starts with “O Canada! Our home and native land!”
questions.feedback: The National Anthem starts with the words “O Canada! Our home and native land!”, the The Royal Anthem starts with “God Save our gracious King!”

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Nunavut Land Claims Agreement Act of 1993 led to the creation of Nunavut in _____.
questions.feedback: The Nunavut Land Claims Agreement Act of 1993 led to the creation of Nunavut in 1999. This was the largest Indigenous land claims settlement in Canadian history, giving the Inuit people greater control over their territory.

questions.question: Who do Canadians vote for in a federal election?
questions.feedback: Canadians vote for a candidate they want to represent them in Parliament
options: 1 A candidate they want to represent them in Parliament
2 The best speaker running in the election
4 All of the candidates in their electoral district

questions.question: What is the role of the Governor General in Canada’s political system?
questions.feedback: The Governor General acts as the Queen’s representative in Canada and is responsible for providing royal assent to bills passed by Parliament.
options: 1 To represent the Queen and provide royal assent to legislation
2 To act as the Prime Minister in the absence of Parliament

questions.question: True or false? The effort by women to achieve the right to travel freely is called the women’s suffrage movement.
questions.feedback: The effort by women to achieve the right to vote is called the women’s suffrage movement. Dr. Emily Stowe was the founder of the women’s suffrage movement in Canada.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. Canada is a parliamentary democracy which means that Canadians elect their representatives to __________.

options: 1 The House of Commons and other legislatures

questions.question: Who started the Marathon of Hope?

questions.question: What are three responsibilities of citizenship?

options: 1 Obeying the law, taking responsibility for oneself and one’s family, serving on a jury
2 Being loyal to Canada, recycling newspapers, serving in the navy, army or air force
3 Learning both official languages, voting in elections, belonging to a union
4 Buying Canadian products, owning your own business, using less water

questions.question: Who are the founding peoples of Canada?
questions.feedback: There are 3 groups of people who helped to start Canada: The Aboriginal people, the French, and the British

questions.question: What do you mark on a federal election ballot?
questions.feedback: You mark an “X” in the circle next to the name of the candidate of your choice on a federal election ballot.

questions.question: True or false? In Canada, men and women are equal under the law.
questions.feedback: In Canada, men and women are equal under the law.

questions.question: Which of the following contributed to the adoption of multiculturalism as an official policy in Canada in 1971?

options: 1 The increasing diversity of immigrant communities
3 Introduction of the The Visitor Visa

questions.question: Who elects the representatives to the House of Commons?
questions.feedback: Canadians elect representatives (Members of Parliament) to the House of Commons.

questions.question: What does a non-confidence vote lead to?
questions.feedback: This is called a non-confidence vote. If a majority of the elected representatives vote that they are not confident that the cabinet ministers are doing their job, then the government is defeated and an election is held.

questions.question: Who proclaimed the amended Constitution of Canada in 1982?
questions.feedback: July 1 used to be called Dominion Day. In 1982, this name was changed to Canada Day. July 1 is Canada Day. We celebrate the anniversary of the Confederation on July 1 every year.

questions.question: What is the largest religious affiliation in Canada?
questions.feedback: The great majority of Canadians identify as Christians. The largest religious affiliation is Catholic, followed by various Protestant churches.

questions.question: Which Canadian province is recognized as officially bilingual at the provincial level?
questions.feedback: New Brunswick is the only officially bilingual province.

questions.question: What is the highest court in Canada?
questions.feedback: Canada’s highest court is called the Supreme Court of Canada.

questions.question: True or false? Canada is a member of the Commonwealth today.

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The capital city of Ontario is __________.
questions.feedback: Toronto is the capital city of Ontario.

questions.question: What is the name of the Royal Anthem of Canada?
questions.feedback: The Royal Anthem of Canada is “God Save the King (or Queen)”. It  can be played or sung on any occasion when Canadians wish to honour the Sovereign.

questions.question: Which legal act formalized the recognition of Indigenous land rights in Canada in 1763?

questions.question: Which of the following was a key element of the Constitution Act, 1982?
questions.feedback: The Constitution Act of 1982 introduced the Charter of Rights and Freedoms, which enshrined the legal and human rights of Canadian citizens.
options: 1 Introduction of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
2 End of Canada’s membership in the Commonwealth
3 End of Canada’s membership in NAFTA
4 Recognition of only French as the official language of Canada

questions.question: Fill in the blank. The Women’s Suffrage Movement was the effort by women to achieve the right to __________.
questions.feedback: The effort by women to achieve the right to vote is called the women’s suffrage movement.

questions.question: Which country borders Canada on the south?
questions.feedback: Along the southern edge of Canada lies the Canada-United States boundary.

questions.question: How are Senators chosen?

options: 1 Senators are appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister
2 By the Premiers of all provinces
3 By the Governor General of Canada

questions.question: How many speak French as their first language in Quebec?

questions.feedback: Remembrance Day is celebrated on 11 November to recall the end of First World War hostilities.

questions.question: True or false? Freedom of prejudice is one of the fundamental freedoms that Canadians enjoy.
questions.feedback: Canadians enjoy four (4) fundamental freedoms: Freedom of conscience and religion, freedom of thought, belief, and opinion and expression, including freedom of speech and of the press, freedom of peaceful assembly, and freedom of association.

questions.feedback: Habeas corpus is the right to challenge unlawful detention by the state and it has come from English common law.

4 All of the candidates in their electoral district

options: 1 Everyone is innocent until proven guilty
2 Guilt is decided by public opinion
3 Innocence is decided by public opinion
4 Everyone is guilty until proven innocent

questions.question: In what industry do most Canadians work?

questions.question: Which of the following Great Lakes is the largest freshwater lake in the world?

questions.feedback: There are different types of police in Canada. (Municipal) police departments, provincial police forces and the RCMP.

questions.question: Who is entitled to vote in Canadian federal elections?

questions.feedback: Getting a job, taking care of one's family and working hard in keeping with one's abilities are three of the six responsibilities of Canadian citizens.

options: 1 Senators are appointed by the Governor General on the advice of the Prime Minister

4 From the Métis word meaning rivers

3 From the ocean to the sea
4 From the water to the earth

questions.question: What is the name of the Royal Anthem of Canada?
